volunteer_experiences:
[{'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'role': 'Facilitator "greening"​ participation of key neighbourhood communities', 'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Friends of the Canal Park in Leiden (Netherlands)', 'logo': None, 'url': None}, 'cause': 'ENVIRONMENT', 'description': 'The "Singelpark" (canal park) is a large initiative of the Leiden Municipality to connect and redesign into the longest urban park in W-Europe the banks of the canals surrounding the (old) inner city of Leiden, Netherlands. The canals were established a few hundred years ago, largely as part of the city's defence structure in times of war but also serving as transport water ways and water management infrastructure. 

The initiative is part of Leiden's significant drive for greening the city to improve urban living conditions, and make it more attractive for both citizens and the increasing number of tourists visiting. The (litteral) 'greening' takes a preference for indigenous plants and trees into account, and also seeks to provide habitat for small mammals, birds, bees and butterflies as well as aquatic life. As such the park connects several monumental and other areas of interest, including old city gates and bridges, mills, musea, the botanical garden and an old astronomic observatory, Rembrandt's birth place, for instance. The route passes along a number of small restaurants and terraces and at places allows for a variety of artistic events and (semi-permanent) art exhibitions.

While this is a municipality initiative with substantial public financing, a large group of businesses and volunteers signed up for support through the "Vrienden van het Singelpark" (Friends of the Canal park) to:
- advise the Municipality on design and implementation
- mobilize participation by adjacent neighbourhood communities and other stakeholders
- raise additional funding
- participate in actual 'on-the-ground' implementation activities'}, {'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'role': 'Chairman', 'company': {'id': None, 'name': "Community Association d'Oude Morsch (Leiden, the Netherlands)", 'logo': None, 'url': None}, 'cause': None, 'description': "'d'Oude Morsch' is a green suburb in the historic inner city of Leiden, the Netherlands. It features a range of historic buildings and places, a (large) museum for etnography and old mills, narrow streets aligned by old houses, several parks and squares. It is surrounded by canals with oldfashioned bridges and has an old historic harbour. The area is characterized by a mix of houses, (national and international) restaurants and pubs with many terraces, hotels, a cinema, student accommodation, a broad spectre of shops and a few other businesses. Overall the area is low on traffic, except for the typical Dutch high volume of bikers, and easy for pedestrians, including many tourists, to cross. The squares frequently host music and other events, and form the center of the annual celebrations of the liberation of Leiden at the end of the 80-year war with Spain.

Issues and challenges comprise urban planning and development in adjacent areas with a spill-over effect to d'Oude Morsch', increased traffic pressure and parking problems, street pollution, noise, and the like - not surprising for an area with a population density of 5.000 persons/km2. The Community Association then, focusses on containing related excesses in conjunction with Leiden Municipality,  actively participates in consultation processes with the municipality and other stakeholders as appropriate, promotes sustainability initiatives (energy, greening), and is in the process of designing a 10-year vision and development plan for the area as reference framework for easy consultation.

"}, {'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'role': 'Tennis trainer for Ukranian refugees', 'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Tennis Club Leidse Hout', 'logo': None, 'url': None}, 'cause': None, 'description': 'A volunteer group undertakes to provide various kinds of support to Ukrainian refugees who are housed in Leiden, The Netherlands. As a member of this group and being a keen tennis player myself, for several hours a week I give tennis training to a group of Ukrainians. Hopefully this takes their mind away from the misery at home for a while and contributes to maintaining their physical wellbeing.'}]
